cards.title: Intro
cards.body: C quick reference cheat sheet that provides basic syntax and methods.

cards.title: hello.c
hello.c
cards.code: $ gcc -Wall -g hello.c -o hello

cards.title: hello.c
cards.code: $ ./hello

cards.title: Comment
Print text
Control the number of spaces
cards.body:
In `%-9d`, `d` means to output in `10` base, `9` means to occupy at least `9` characters width, and the width is not
enough to fill with spaces, `-` means left alignment

cards.title: Strings
cards.code:

printf("%s", greetings);

cards.title: Strings

printf("%c", greetings[0]);

cards.title: Strings
Strings
cards.body:
**NOTE**: String literals might be stored in read-only section of memory. Modifying a string literal invokes undefined
behavior. You can't modify it!

cards.title: Strings
cards.body: `C` **does not** have a String type, use `char` type and create an `array` of characters

cards.title: Condition

cards.code:
int age = 20;
(age > 19) ? printf("Adult\n") : printf("Teenager\n");

memory address
cards.body: When a variable is created, it is assigned a memory address

cards.title: memory address
memory address
cards.body: To access it, use the reference operator (`&`)

cards.title: create pointer
pointer variable
cards.code:
int myAge = 43; // an int variable
int*ptr = &myAge; // pointer variable named ptr, used to store the address of myAge

printf("%d\n", myAge); // print the value of myAge (43)

printf("%p\n", &myAge); // output the memory address of myAge (0x7ffe5367e044)
printf("%p\n", ptr); // use the pointer (0x7ffe5367e044) to output the memory address of myAge

cards.title: Dereference
Comparison Operators
Comparison Operators
cards.back: greater than or equal to | x `>=` y

cards.title: Comparison Operators
cards.back: less than or equal to | x `<=` y

cards.title: Comparison Operators
cards.body: Comparison operators are used to compare two values

cards.title: Logical Operators
cards.back: `and` logical | returns true if both statements are true | `x < 5 && x < 10`

cards.title: Logical Operators
cards.back: \ | | `or` logical | returns true if one of the statements is true | x < 5 \ | \ | x < 4

cards.title: Logical Operators
cards.back: `not` logical | Invert result, return false if true | `!(x < 5 && x < 10)`

cards.title: Operator Examples
Bitwise operators
cards.back: Bitwise AND operation, "AND" operation by binary digits | `(A & B)` will get `12` which is 0000 1100

cards.title: Bitwise operators
cards.back: | Bitwise OR operator, "or" operation by binary digit | (A \ | B) will get`61` which is 0011 1101

cards.title: Bitwise operators
cards.back: XOR operator, perform "XOR" operation by binary digits | `(A ^ B)` will get `49` which is 0011 0001

cards.title: Bitwise operators
cards.back: Inversion operator, perform "inversion" operation by binary bit | `(~A)` will get `-61` which is 1100 0011

cards.title: Bitwise operators
cards.back: binary left shift operator | `A << 2` will get `240` which is 1111 0000

cards.title: Bitwise operators
cards.back: binary right shift operator | `A >> 2` will get `15` which is 0000 1111

cards.title: Predefined macros
cards.back: Defined as `1` when the compiler compiles against the `ANSI` standard

cards.title: Predefined macros
cards.body: `ANSI C` defines a number of macros that you can use, but you cannot directly modify these predefined macros

cards.title: Predefined macros
Macro continuation operator (\\)
cards.body: A macro is usually written on a single line.

cards.title: Macro continuation operator (\\)
cards.code:
#define message_for(a, b) \
    printf(#a " and " #b ": We love you!\n")

cards.title: Macro continuation operator (\\)
cards.body: If the macro is too long to fit on a single line, use the macro continuation operator `\`

cards.title: String Constantization Operator (#)
String Constantization Operator (#)
cards.body: When the above code is compiled and executed, it produces the following result:

cards.title: String Constantization Operator (#)
cards.code: Carole and Debra: We love you!

cards.title: String Constantization Operator (#)
cards.body: When you need to convert a macro parameter to a string constant, use the string constant operator `#`

defined() operator

cards.body: The macro rewrites the above code as follows:

cards.title: Parameterized macros
cards.code: #define square(x) ( (x) * (x) )

cards.title: Parameterized macros
cards.body: No spaces are allowed between the macro name and the opening parenthesis

cards.body: The function consists of two parts

cards.title: Function declaration and definition
Function declaration and definition
cards.body:
• `Declaration` declares the function name, return type and parameters _(if any)_
• `Definition` function body _(code to execute)_

Mathematical functions
Mathematical functions
cards.body:
• `abs(x)` absolute value
• `acos(x)` arc cosine value
• `asin(x)` arc sine
• `atan(x)` arc tangent
• `cbrt(x)` cube root
• `cos(x)` cosine
• the value of `exp(x)` Ex
• `sin(x)` the sine of x
• tangent of `tan(x)` angle

cards.title: Create structure
cards.code:
struct MyStructure { // structure declaration
  int myNum; // member (int variable)
  char myLetter; // member (char variable)
}; // end the structure with a semicolon

cards.title: Create structure
Create structure
cards.code:
## File Processing ### File processing function | Function | Description | | ----------- | :------------------------------------------------ | | `fopen()` | `open` a new or existing file | | `fprintf()` | write data to `file` | | `fscanf()` | `read` data from a file | | `fputc()` | write a character to `file` | | `fgetc()` | `read` a character from a file | | `fclose()` | `close` the file | | `fseek()` | set the file pointer to `the given position` | | `fputw()` | Write an integer `to` a file | | `fgetw()` | `read` an integer from a file | | `ftell()` | returns the current `position` | | `rewind()` | set the file pointer to the beginning of the file | {.show-header} There are many functions in the C library to `open`/`read`/`write`/`search` and `close` files ### Open mode parameter | Mode | Description | | ----- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `r` | Open a text file in `read` mode, allowing the file to be read | | `w` | Open a text file in `write` mode, allowing writing to the file | | `a` | Open a text file in `append` mode
If the file does not exist, a new one will be created | | `r+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `w+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `a+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `rb` | Open a binary file in `read` mode | | `wb` | Open binary file in `write` mode | | `ab` | Open a binary file in `append` mode | | `rb+` | open binary file in `read-write` mode | | `wb+` | Open binary file in `read-write` mode | | `ab+` | open binary file in `read-write` mode | {.show-header} ### Open the file: fopen()

cards.title: Create structure

cards.code:
After performing all operations on the file, the file must be closed with `fclose()`
